repnme.cdata!:
Uruguay - Second Phase (APL-2) of the OSE
            Modernization and Systems Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase (APL-2) of
            the OSE (National water Supply and Sanitation Company -
            Obras Sanitarias del Estado) Modernization and Systems
            Rehabilitation Project for Uruguay were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: OSE's senior management commitment to enhance
            utility performance and the Bank's long term
            relationship with OSE promoted innovation and institutional
            reform. The Adaptable Program Loan (APL) instrument and an
            experienced implementation unit played a key role in the
            project's full disbursement and on-time completion. The
            Bank's global knowledge and convening power played a
            key role in transforming OSE into an outward looking
            utility. Prior to the project, OSE had a reputation for
            being an inward looking utility. Focusing on best practices
            is oftentimes more important than focusing on numeric
            results. Human capacity development is a key to sustainably
            reducing Non-Revenue Water (NRW). OSE found that human
            capacity development was perhaps the most essential tool for
            reducing water losses and that companywide day-to-day
            operations have the greatest impact on NRW reduction.

17151645.projn:
UY-Apl2 Ose Modernization & Systems
            Rehabilitation Project -- P101432
17151645.theme: Urban Economic Development,City-wide Infrastructure and Service Delivery

repnme.cdata!:
Uruguay - Second Phase (APL-2) of the OSE
            Modernization and Systems Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Phase
            (APL-2) of the National Water Supply and Sanitation Company
            (OSE) Modernization and Systems Rehabilitation Project is to
            ensure Uruguayans receive more accountable, customer
            orientated and better value for money, water and sanitation
            services. After an in-depth Mid-Term Review (MTR) of the
            project in December 2011, the Bank team and OSE proposed a
            restructuring to: (i) measure the Non Revenue Water (NRW)
            intermediate indicators using a metric that is now
            considered industry best practice and will provide a more
            detailed understanding of the NRW reduction program's
            progress; and (ii) adjust the environmental intermediate
            indicators to better align them with OSE's current
            vision for environmental management.

display_title.display_title:
Uruguay - Second Phase (APL-2) of
            the OSE Modernization and Systems Rehabilitation Project :
            restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!: Modernizing public water services in Uruguay

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            modernizing public water services in Uruguay. Given
            Uruguay’s public utilities like water, electricity and
            telecommunications were monopolies in their respective
            sectors, which has made it difficult to benchmark and
            provide entry points to improve performance. In addition,
            the country’s public water and sanitation utility lagged
            behind other public service providers in terms of
            operational performance and customer service. The
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            worked with Uruguay to modernize its water utility company,
            Obras Sanitarias del Estado (OSE), helping in its
            transformation from an inefficient monopoly into a more
            accountable public utility providing better quality water to
            more Uruguayans than ever before. With the help of IBRD,
            Uruguay’s OSE had slowly evolved from a highly inefficient
            water utility into a solid one over the course of the last
            two decades. As a result of IBRD involvement, Uruguay has
            created a more transparent and accountable water sector.
            OSE, which formerly acted as de facto policymaker and
            regulator in addition to service provider in the water
            sector, has become a part of a wider system that includes an
            autonomous water and electricity regulator, and a separate
            policy-making agency, created in 2006.

            modernizing public water services in Uruguay. Given
